title: When a professional killer is a good person...
content: This is one of those strange films where people who are supposed to be 'bad guys' are actually the 'good guys' in the story. Léon is a professional killer who can't do anything but kill. He's almost perfect when he works, but has one weak point: women and children. I don't know if such a character is possible in real life, and I'm not sure about the message of the film, if there's any, but the fact is that I find good acting, good music and a film with which you don't get bored. My rating is 7 out of 10.

title: That was an excellent one.
content: I have a quite specific criteria for rating a movie. It is by how memorable it is. It is by how much it shows you moments, dialogs, situations that get into your mind and which you think over and over again after the movie, without necessarily finding a deep philosophical meaning in them. Moments that left you enough of an impression to force you review and analyze them thoroughly. This film gives me what I am looking for. Leon and Mathilda are excellent characters and you really embrace their personalities, their spirit, their hardships, you watch their actions with agony and feel their will for carrying on in a cruel,unforgiving world. Stansfield is also excellent as the villain and shows the other side of the coin, that is how easy it is to fall into immorality and how much power that can give you in the system we live today. Go and watch that movie. I promise it will be memorable.

title: Simply Perfect
content: I consider myself as a fan of action movies and movies in general. When i first saw this movie i thought it was just incredible to see Natalie Portman so young and acting so well. After seen it like 10 times i realize that Gary Oldman is a genius, Jean Reno's role has an unique personality and the hole movie is just amazing. Is one of those movies you love even more when you saw it again. Like a the fifth time you see it you can start appreciating some details, like the music or even the sounds. It reminds me the old action films where you thought everything was very meticulous and done with experts before great technology appeared. Movies like Die Hard, those you appreciate because the story is really original and the characters can trap you and question your beliefs.

title: deep feeling
content: I am a person who gets very emotional personally, and there are few things in this world that can evoke my true emotions. One of those very powerful things is the acting of this little girl that makes my heart skip a beat and makes me feel something that I can't talk about. How is it possible for a girl at such a young age to present such a strong performance? I feel that this girl never acted in this movie and she was her real self in the whole movie. I loved this very strong and deep movie and it is at the top of my movie list. I hope that every person who can feel as little as I can, by watching this movie, can taste a little taste of the deep feeling that I felt and it doesn't even have a name. But I will say this, this deep sensation isn't supposed to be pleasant, it's just supposed to remind you that you're alive and breathing. And this deep painful feeling, in addition to being close to the door, shows you the deep meaning of human contact with life. Unpleasant like life, but necessary.

title: Excellent movie.
content: Best movie that i've ever seen. Great exciting scenario and wonderful actor play captures from the beginning to the end.

title: Max your life...
content: Ah, monsieur, you can lead a Frenchman to the Big Apple, but you can't make him a New Yorker and that's exactly what makes The Professional so fascinating. Oldman is the least constructed expectable actor of his generation, and as this deranged detective, he keeps absolutely nothing in reserve. Few action films can claim such complexities without conceding the bang-bang stuff that brings in the big money. Besson's visuals are, as always, vibrant and decidedly. With some surprisingly strong character interaction, there's a lot to like about this movie, at least for those willing to look beyond all the bloodshed. The sheer oddness of the New York world for this film where cops and crooks are literally stranded in roles that pick over the leavings of earlier parts..!?

title: Not worth the watch......
content: Ok, it seems like I'm going against the grain here, but after watching Leon: The Professional (Widescreen DVD: International ver) I was very discontented.  For starters, I was introduced to the movie with the understanding that it was an action flick, it wasn't.  I was told that I would really care about the characters, I didn't.  Here's the deal:Gary Oldman is one of my favorite actors.  I like him to play villains and in this movie he does a very well job.  He's evil, clever and extremely threatening.  Unfortunately, his character is given little screen time.Natalie Portman shows that she is a great actress.  After seeing what I believe is her first film I can understand why she could have a successful film career in front of her.Jean Reno.  Um....He seems to do as much as he can with the role.  I like him in other films but there's not a lot you can do with a character who seems extremely smart at times but mentally retarded at others.The movie starts out great but comes to a screeching halt about 1/4 of the way through then climbs back up to about 3/4 speed towards the end. Matilda's relationship with Leon is strained and borders pedophilia. Matilda continually advances on Leon sexually.  Could this film not have accomplished the feeling of comradely without the thought of a sexually active 12 year old attempting to seduce a 35ish year old man?Other than that major plot dampener, we are continually bombarded with silly things that do little if nothing to the story. (Such as Matilda dressing up like Madonna, Marilyn & Charlie Chaplin.) Her continual use of the F-bomb is annoying and after the first 10 times she says it you start to ask yourself if you like this little girl of if she's just annoying.  Luc Besson does add some clever camera movements into the film as well as some interesting and funny characteristics into Leon.All in all I found myself glancing away from the screen and checking just how long the movie had been running on the LCD read out.  The painfully predictable ending was just that, painful.  If you have nothing to do on a Monday night when it's raining outside and there's nothing on, then watch Leon: The Professional.  But keep the remote handy with your finger on Fast Forward.  You'll probably need it.

title: Not exactly what I expected
content: I don't understand all the hype about this movie,there are absolutely nothing special about it, the main idea of the movie was already used before! there are some really "hollywoodian" scenes that are frustrating to see how much fake it is, and not only the action scenes; I don't think that a 12 year old girl that smokes would be amazed by that piggy excuse to make the movie more sentimental. At least there are some good acting, Gary Oldman did a nice job; Jean Reno was also nice; Natalie Portman was good enough for a child. But, in compensation, there are some really bad actors that ruins most of the good acting.

title: Even with its flaws, it's a pretty entertaining film.
content: The too-cool-for-words French actor Jean Reno plays the title role, a hitman earning a living in NYC. One of his neighbors is the precocious Mathilda (Natalie Portman, in her film debut), who lives with trashy parents, a foul-tempered sister, and one innocent, her baby brother. Then one day, crooked, psychotic, and pill-popping D. E. A. Agent Stansfield (Gary Oldman) and his crew wipe out the rest of Mathildas' family. She finds a safe haven living with Leon, and becomes obsessed with the thought of revenge. She URGES him to teach her the tricks of his trade; with great reluctance, he becomes her mentor and father figure.Written and directed by Luc Besson (who'd made a big splash with "La Femme Nikita" previously), "Leon" is not without its share of problems. For one thing, it can get pretty ridiculous at times; master stylist Besson is not exactly going for gritty reality here. Also, some of the scenes with Leon and Mathilda, who's obviously in TOO much of a hurry to grow up (and who thinks she loves Leon), are very uncomfortable. (This, despite the fact that we can sense that Leon is a basically good man who won't take advantage of her.) It also threatens to go off the rails because of Oldman, whose performance is often quite over the top. (His "EVERYOOOONE!" scene has become iconic over the years.)All of this said, the film is a compelling combination of dark elements, drama, humor, action ("Leon" gets operatically violent at times), and tension. What really makes the difference is that Reno has such presence on screen, and his rapport with young Portman, who likewise gives such a natural performance for a beginner that it's as if she'd been acting for years. Reno chose to play Leon as a simple-minded, almost childlike man, one who dotes on a plant and loves movie musicals, and this makes him quite appealing. They're supported by a number of familiar faces: Danny Aiello as Tony, the guy who gives Leon his assignments, Ellen Greene and Michael Badalucco as Mathildas' parents, and George Martin, Kent Broadhurst, and Robert LaSardo.Most amusing is the montage of assassinations where Leon and Mathilda are working as a team.Seven out of 10.

title: pretentious garbage

Pseudo art film cinematography can't compensate for cartoon characters and a plot out of a comic book. Nor can a precocious and talented 13-year old actress uttering total nonsense. title: "Yes, life always that hard"
content: It's a very sad story, especially at the end of the movie. It was a deep dive for me and I need some time to get back to my own life. Based only on this feeling I can call it a great movie and recommend to watch.

title: Brilliant, touching and confronting
content: This film displays outstanding portrayals of different characters, a clever and touching screenplay and fantastic cinematography.Acting: A young Natalie Portman performs with skill and grace. title: One of the best crime films of the 80s or 90s...
content: My rating: 9,0/10Is actually a bit cheesy at times. But overall the film is very effective, and effective in all aspects. Starting with the cinematography: an oppressive look in the interior scenes _ houses with tight halls and grimy walls_ and a cold, desolated one in the exterior scenes _with a mostly gray palette of colors, streets with big corners and dead ends. This odd, dark ambient, added to a lovely romantic soundtrack, gives this film a distinct, perfect atmosphere.*About the story:*"There is poetry in the dialogs, and there is definitely some artistry put in this film. Is very similar to TDK in that aspect. Very good character development, something extremely rare in this sort of film. A few things felt forced here and there, but overall, a good and moving story about a kid growing up all by herself in a totally hostile environment."*And to finish, the acting:*"Great performances by Oldman, Reno and Portman. They are definitely the highlights of the film. Oldman is a scene stealer here, with his ultra over the top acting."*Conclusion...One of the best crime films of the 80s or 90s.

title: Beautiful love story
content: Generally a love story about a 40 year old man who lives by himself and a 12 year old girl would go down about as well as a porkpie at a Jewish wedding with cries of paedophilia from far and wide.  However Leon is just that - a love story, everything else is incidental or situation, and has become a modern classic.What makes this work is that Leon is the 40 year old but appears more naive and childlike, while Mathilda is the grown up in a 12 year old's body - a modern version of Lolita.  The love between them is a pure love, like the relationship between two children, where Leon protects Mathilda and cares for her and Mathilda provides a life that fills the cold existence of Leon's hitman-focused lifestyle.Portman is excellent in this role - she has yet to do anything better, Reno is well cast and handles the opening up of his character in a very believable fashion - he is totally convincing as a killer and a nervous child making friends for the first time.  Oldman overacts like a madman!  If you look closely at his shirt sleeves you'll see his cuff links are actually pineapple rings because he's such a big ham!  His performance doesn't sit well beside the others and he seems to be in a different movie at times. However he does bring a cold killer element with it that works well and offsets his eccentricities.A classic love story, look beyond the guns at the two central performances and you'll see one of the most beautiful relationships in modern films.  The ending will fill you with happiness and break your heart in equal measure.

title: Looks cheap and feels awkward
content: When it works, it really works. Reno is great, Portman is impressive, the two have great chemistry, and the action scenes are exhilarating. When it doesn't work, though, it really doesn't work. Oldman is basically playing the same role he was stuck with throughout the 90s (though he gives it his all), the direction is bland and damn near amateurish, the whole film looks cheap, and the core relationship, while developed well, leaves a bad taste in one's month. A little too much awkward sexual tension. I think the problem is that Portman's role was written for someone older, and, as such, she just seems too young. It's rather overrated, and it's also dated by some terrible, terrible music choices.

title: A classic
content: It's a much sparer film than many of Luc's others (particularly his subsequent ones), and has a definite small-scale feel about it, which is a good thing. It's brilliantly scripted and directed, and superbly paced...long periods of calm, leading up to bursts of intense action. The humour works well, too.Jean Reno is absolutely top-notch as Leon, the awkward, shy guy who becomes an invisible killing machine whenever he goes to work, and exhibits a sort of childish glee when watching Gene Kelly on the big screen. He's funny, deep, mature and childlike all at the same time, and it's a pleasure to watch.Nat, too, is simply amazing. It's her first movie, and she's only around twelve or thirteen, but I don't think she's given a more accomplished performance since (at least, not in a movie I'm willing to watch). The bit where she's standing at Leon's door sobbing her little eyes out kills me every time.It's nice to see Gary Oldman playing a villain for once ;). He's in peak form here, as a linen suit-wearing, pill-popping, Beethoven-loving, ultra-violent sociopath. He's a total nut-bag, but very cool with it. Even when he's slaughtering innocent women and children, you can't help but like him.Or, is that just me...?Eric Serra's score actually WORKS this time. In some movies I find all that weird, French, electronic stuff distracting. Not here.I'm trying to think of bad points about this film, but can't come up with any. I guess that says it all really.

title: Charming characters with decent performances
content: While the sum of the film leaves you with little to chew on, I found Jean Reno's performance captivatingly charming, Gary Oldman hilariously over the top, and Nathalie Portman fairs just fine as far as child actors go. But outside of that it feels as though the back drop of murder and violence serves as simple action fodder. Nor does it excel in this regard, and since it's less commentary on violence and more violence as a tool for engaging the audience it lacks the depth or excitement you crave from the genre. It is also a film that did not completely know how to end. While I sympathize with writers everywhere on the difficulty of endings, it does not excuse what seems to be a complete lack of effort to tie the story up (or not tie it up, either way it should embrace a certain tone rather then... we'll nothing at all). This is by no means a bad movie, but I find myself enjoying the idea of the film over the film itself.

title: What a difference it makes if u watch after 10 years...
content: Two days ago I watched Leon after little more than 10 years since I last saw the movie in a theater. I had fond memories of getting goose bums last time around. But this time around the feeling was completely opposite. I couldn't even finish watching the DVD. Stopped watching just when the last fight scene was about to start... After watching movies over the years, realized Leon is just another flick made by Hollywood with all the formulas and recipes they use repeatedly to make the mass dumber and dumber. The dialogues were so awful. Both the main actors were unbearable this time around. The so-called anti hero is given a set of activities to make him look villainous... I have watched movies like Godfather, Lost in Translation a number of times. Each time I appreciate the thought process that went into making such movies. But Leon is completely out of my list of movies. Don't regret the money spend on buying the DVD, but the time wasted...

title: A stunningly well made film
content: This is another one of these films which surprised me with how good it was. My expectations for this film were not high because I had got it into my head that this was a self indulgent tale from a French director. Quite where I had got that idea from I have no idea but i was so wrong. This is one of my favourite films of all time. I love the feel of this film, I never felt comfortable for any of the characters at any time, I never really knew what the next frame would turn out to be and in many ways it was a depressing film. I think there are a lot of people out there who could identify with the character of Leon in this film because if its not yourself it could be somebody who just doesn't seem to fit in anywhere apart from one tiny aspect of life as a whole. The story is told in a dramatic and violent manner but because of the subject matter it is entirely in context. Please give this film a viewing and enjoy this stunningly made film.

title: It's a poorly done fantasy
content: The characters are ridiculously cartoonish, because the important part here is the fantasy about a romance between a childish adult man and a "mature for her age" young girl.But with a pathetically basic story poorly developed (if developed at all), bad dialogue (for the most part), romantic scenes in the middle of cold "ugly" violence, and surreal characters that suck and have no grow or depth (or both), this is just a poorly done fantasy instead of the exploration of a complicated or questionable relationship.

title: After 27 years...
content: So why now, after first seeing this movie on its original theatrical run 27 years ago at London's Odeon, Kensington High Street do I suddenly feel the need to write a review of a movie I've since watched countless times? I guess it was receiving the 4K blu-ray of the movies as a birthday present and sitting down to watch it again that was the catalyst but in all fairness, I should have done it a long time ago..I'm going to assume at this point that nobody reading this hasn't seen this movie. If, by some quirk of fate, you haven't...well, stop reading now and go and watch it, that would be a far more productive use of your time. Given that everybody else reading has seen it, I just want to make a couple of observations on this remarkable piece of work.Perhaps the most obvious thing about this movie is absolutely NO WAY would it get made today. Hollywood's woke mafia would pretty quickly see to that. The pitch meeting for a proposed movie in which an orphaned and therefore vulnerable twelve year old girl and a middle aged Italian immigrant hit man enter into a dubious relationship would be a wonder to behold - I'd pay to see that! The movie itself is in no way problematic in this respect, with Leon himself being more of a 'child' than Mathilda is. Still, the issue is an obvious sticking point...I can remember leaving the theater 27 years ago with my friend Tim and, for most of the drive home, he remained quite - most unlike him. After a while, he sheepishly said '...I found that girl attractive. Is that a problem?' to which I laughed and said reassuringly 'you were meant to, that's the whole idea!'All these years later, Leon remains Luc Besson's finest work by quite some way. I enjoyed 'The Fifth Element', 2014's Scarlett Johansson-fronted Sci-fi romp Lucy and even the B-movie mediocracy of Anna. Nothing the man has done before or since matches the artistry of Leon. Story, casting and execution came together perfectly on this movie, the stars were aligned. I don't give marks of 10, that's perfection. Perfection doesn't exist and so I'll go with a 9...

title: The Best Movie
content:
It is one of the best movies I have watched, and one of the best movies in the world cinema.John Lennon is a wonderful actor that I admire a lot.This movie is worth watching again and again
Every time I watch Leon is as gripping and enjoyable as the first.Leon is one of the most emotionally intense movies ever made.French director Luc Besson uses everything: actors, music, camera angles, lighting to create an unique experience - "It's not realism, it's not naturalism - it's heightened reality" as Gary Oldman very well put it.This movie can make you wonder.The Best Movie Ever The Professional.

title: Wonderful
content: How can I rate this unique movie less than a 10. Intelligent dialogues, strong emotional build-up, fast pace, absorbing atmosphere and a great soundtrack.But Leon would be doomed without first class actors. All four main characters are perfectly cast and brilliantly played. Their presence dominates this movie, which by the way has nothing to do with an action flick, it is a masterfully crafted character study. Action is just the extra salt to the delicious cinematic plate Luc Besson is offering to us.Natalie Portman requires a special praise. This is not only a stunning performance from a 12 year old girl, this is even not only a great performance from an accomplished actress, it is absolutely Oscar material and, judging from her next projects, easily her best role to date.It is no coincidence that Luc Besson, Eric Serra and Jean Reno are French. They know how to go past the surface and make a movie with a feeling.

title: A Movie Of Extremes & Fascinating
content: This is one of the truly sick movies I own and am embarrassed to say how much I have always liked it....but I have, big-time. This film, with some very sick messages, is uniquely appealing at the same time. To use a popular word of today: it is "extreme."The extreme GOOD: 1 - A very different story and a fascinating profile of a strange, likable loner hit-man and a tough little girl and how they help each other soften the other's personality; 2 - A very intense drama at times with tremendous action scenes in the beginning and end, particularly the latter. 3 - The little girl "Mathilda" (Natalie Portman's first role) does of the best acting jobs I've ever seen for pre-teen child, and I've seen a number of good ones over the years. It is no surprise she has turned out to be a big star. 4 - Despite his profession, "Leon" (Jean Reno) is a very likable character and extremely contradictory, extolling admirable virtues to the little girl (no cursing, no smoking, choosing good friends, etc.) while at the same time teaching her how to shoot people and then using her as an accomplice to murders! Reno's voice is fun to listen to, really different from any other actor I've ever heard. 5 - Gary Oldman, as usual, is great at playing a whacked-out character. The more you watch this film, the more you appreciate his performance. 6 - A very satisfying ending; 7 - Great camera shots by director Luc Besson, who is known for some stylish movie-making.The extreme BAD: 1 - Not only does nice-guy Leon teach Mathilda how to shoot people but.... 2 - the latter (on the extended version) gets drunk and later wants Leon to make love to her ; 3 - Portman uses strong profanity throughout the film. I'm sorry, but a little girl doing and saying all of this is pretty sick! (What kind of parents, by the way, would allow their 11-year-old to play a role like this?) 4 - Another film that makes a killer into the good guy and the police into the bad guys.In the end, though, it's only a movie, just a fictional story and it's job is to entertain....and in that it succeeds amazingly well. Great entertainment in a perverse way.

title: Jean Reno Is My Hero For Life!!!
content: This is the first Jean Reno film I saw. After this one, I saw many of his other films as well. BUT THIS ONE IS MY FAVORITE! The role fits him like a glove, and it seems to me to be made only for him. He gives us his emotional best in the film.The other great star in this film that complements him is Natalie Portman who plays her film debut at 12 years of age. Natalie plays the role of Mathilda, Leon's (Jean Reno) neighbour. Her acting is simply phenomenal. But like most child stars (a good example is Macaulay Culkin (Home Alone)) she does not do well as an adult actress. Anyway this IS HER BEST FILM.Now we are going to say something about the super actor called Gary Oldman. He is SUPER!!! My god I haven't seen anyone act like this before. This guy really gets into the act!!! This is ALSO HIS BEST FILM.Now when the 3 actors above all give their best, enough is said.Full Plot: Leone "Léon" Montana (Jean Reno) is a hit-man (or "cleaner," as he refers to himself) living a solitary life in New York City's Little Italy. His work comes from a mafioso named Tony (Danny Aiello), who operates from the "Supreme Macaroni Company" restaurant. Léon spends his idle time engaging in calisthenics, nurturing a houseplant that early on he describes as his "best friend,"[3] and (in one scene) watching old Gene Kelly musicals.On a particular day, he meets Mathilda Lando (Natalie Portman), a twelve-year-old girl with a black eye and smoking a cigarette, living with her dysfunctional family in an apartment down the hallway. Her abusive father and self-involved mother aren't even aware that Mathilda has stopped attending class at her upscale school.Mathilda's father (Michael Badalucco) attracts the ire of corrupt DEA agents, who have been paying him to store cocaine in his residence, after they discover that he has been stealing some of the drugs for himself. A cadre of DEA agents storm the building, led by a sharp-suited and drug-addicted Norman "Stan" Stansfield (Gary Oldman), who murders Mathilda's entire family, missing her only because she was out shopping when they arrived. When she returns and notices the carnage, she calmly continues down the hallway and receives sanctuary from a reluctant Léon.Mathilda discovers that Léon is a hit-man. She begs him to become her caretaker and to teach her his skills as a "cleaner;" she wants to avenge the murder of her four-year-old brother, the only member of her family she loved. Léon shows her how to use firearms, including a scoped rifle. In return, she offers her services as a maid and teacher, remedying Léon's illiteracy. Mathilda admits to Léon several times that she is falling in love with him, but he says nothing back.After increasing her experience with firearms, Mathilda fills a shopping bag with guns from Léon's collection and sets out to kill Stansfield. She bluffs her way into the DEA office by posing as a delivery person, only to be ambushed by Stansfield in a bathroom. Léon, discovering her intentions in a note left for him, rushes to rescue Mathilda, shooting two of Stansfield's men in the process.Stansfield is enraged that what he calls the "Italian hit-man" has gone rogue. He threatens Tony, coercing him into surrendering Léon's whereabouts. As soon as Mathilda returns home from grocery shopping, an NYPD ESU team, sent by Stansfield, takes her hostage and attempts to infiltrate Léon's apartment. Léon ambushes the ESU team and barters one agent for Mathilda's freedom. In the apartment, Léon creates a quick escape for Matilda by chopping a hole in a slender air shaft. He reassures her and tells her that he loves her, moments before the police come for him.In the chaos that follows, Léon sneaks out of the apartment building disguised as a wounded ESU officer. He is unnoticed save for Stansfield, who recognizes the hit-man and shoots him. Stansfield jeers him haughtily. Léon places an object in Stansfield's hands, which he explains is "from Mathilda," then he dies. Opening his hands, Stansfield recognizes it as the pin from a grenade. He rips open Léon's vest to discover several grenades on his chest, right before a massive explosion kills him.Mathilda heads to Tony's place as she was instructed to do by Léon. Tony will not give Mathilda more than a small amount of the fortune Léon had amassed, which Tony was holding for him. He offers a monthly allowance and says school should be her priority for now. Mathilda asks Tony to give her a job, insisting that she can "clean" as Léon had. Tony sternly informs her that he "ain't got no work for a 12-year-old kid!" Having nowhere else to go, Mathilda makes her way to New Jersey in an attempt to return to school. After telling her and Léon's story to the headmistress, and seemingly being readmitted, Mathilda walks into a field near the school with Léon's houseplant in hand. She digs a hole and plants it, as she had told Léon he should, "to give it roots."Verdict: 10/10. Buy the FULL UNCUT EDITION on DVD

title: I didn't think I'd find a better movie about a hit-man than Grosse Pointe Blank... but I did in spades.
content: This film is the story of a very smart and calculating professional killer named Leon (Jean Reno) who ends up with a burden in his arms, a twelve year old girl named Matilda (Natalie Portman). Matilda's fate is almost met when a very crooked DEA Agent Stansfield (Gary Oldman) murders her family while she is out buying milk - Leon saves her life and teaches her the trade of "cleaning". I bought this film before I had even seen it. I did this because of the fantastic reviews it got, and having a real respect for Gary Oldman. When I fired it up the first time... it all suddenly made sense.The real story behind Leon isn't the gun play, (which is still fantastic) but the relationship between mature well mannered Leon and sexually inexperienced and unsure, but outgoing Matilda. The chemistry between the two on screen is just fantastic, as Leon starts to come to terms with himself that he really is in love with Matilda. Pedhophila is an issue in this film (though is never shown) and is understandable why some people find it to be a hard pill to swallow (maybe not for Oldman)... but for me, this film is like taking a trip down a road of rocky revenge, heartbreaking tragedy, breathtaking style and substance to die for. See Leon today.

title: Besson's Best
content: A nice action/drama piece that mixes assassin style rumblings with the sentimentality of a 'lost' girl looking for a 'father/boyfriend'.The relationship between the two, occasionally borders on the creepy depending on your perspective (Polanski style) but generally its played well.Both characters are a little off beat which is what makes this movie work so well.Genuinely interesting and engaging and worthy of a look.

title: A much more tender affair than you'd expect.
content: 'Léon: The Professional (1994)' is a much more tender affair than you'd expect, one that's not so much driven by the eponymous assassin's life-meddling day-job but by his surprisingly human home-life and the relationships he forms during a time where both begin to catastrophically collide. The central dynamic is a little odd, though it's nothing compared to what was in the original screenplay, but ultimately turns out sweetly serene and incidentally innocent. The scenery-chewing villain is a little pantomime but menacingly hunts down the duo like dogs, which allows for some great action set-pieces punctuated by pure emotional moments. 7/10

title: Seen it 20+ times
content: Giving this movie a 10 because it's rewatchable. Love Besson movies, great casts and absolutely unique soundtracks. Gary Oldman is a gem of the british acting scene. Great acting from a young Natalie Portman as well.

title: One of the top 10 movies ever
content: This might equally well have been entitled 'Mathilda' for there is no question it is Natalie Portman who steals the show from the merely brilliant Jean Reno (who should have got an Oscar for this.) Gary Oldman is as good being bad as ever, and Danny Aiello provides a classy supporting role.The movie could be controversial in many respects but the sheer class and emotion lift it above any doubt. It reflects real life. Perhaps surprisingly, it is in Leon that emotion surfaces more easily, with Mathilda almost carrying the hardened hit-man as well as the film, through a series of punishing tests.Mathilda is irresistible, cute, practical, tortured, sensual, and yet remains entirely innocent. As is the heartless, simple, cold-blooded murderer, Leon. This is artistic, entertaining, depressing, uplifting, shocking, yet always remains beautiful and true.It is sad that Portman has never come anywhere near to repeating her performance in Leon, and probably never will. Whatever reasons she may have, it is sad for the fans that she doesn't take on more of these 'gritty' roles. But it's one more reason to watch, be amazed and captivated by Leon.

title: See the long version!
content: When I in 1994 first saw Leon at the movies I was shocked. I didn´t expect much when I got there, but when I left I had a strange feeling in my body. It caught me. Bessons cameratechnic is fantastic. Portman, Aiëllo and Oldman are very convincing. But what makes the diffrence is Jean Reno. France's far most talented actor. His shy professional acting makes one believe he never done anything else in his life. It was one of the best films I had ever seen. I even namned my bird Leon. When I in 97 laid my hands on the long version (released in Sweden, Denmark, France and a few more places. NOT USA!) I realised that it was my favourite movie and it still is.

title: Absolutely Brilliant
content: I knew I loved this movie, but after revisiting it after about a decade, it still stands up -- No, it more than stands up. Like a good wine, it actually gets better with age. I just watched it with my 13-year old son, a budding film enthusiast, and he just flat-out loved it. Great story, top-of-the-line performances by Portman, Reno and Oldman, wonderful direction. Even the music is great! What more can I say? This stands the test of time and stands proudly among the best ever made. This time around, I was particularly impressed with the artistic mixture of drama, action and comedy. Besson knows exactly where the camera should be at all times to tell an entertaining, gripping and touching story that is both daring and caring. Hard to do!

title: Only One Criticism
content: Judging by other user's comments, I must be the only one who thought Gary Oldman was a little too angry and crazy to be believable. The scenes of his ingesting drugs were overacted to the point of being humorous, which was not intended. The rest of the film was wonderful.

title: Good movie but left me feeling uncomfortable
content: I want to start of by saying that I watched the directors cut, so it included a lot of scenes that I did not particularly appreciate, hence only the 7/10.Natalie Portman is fantastic in her role. To be able to achieve this level of acting at such a young age is something we must truly appreciate. It feels very natural and very easy to her. She was born te be an actress!Same can be said about Jean Reno's performance. He portrays the character in a very fragile way and he was able to make me feel 'bad' for a hitman. I was emotionally involved with him and I felt for him during the movie.Gary Oldman's best performance as the deranged head of the DEA also adds to the reasons as to why this movie could've been great, but let's talk about the 'bad' now.The plot was ridiculous in many ways to be honest. There was no backstory for Gary Oldman's character and it felt weird that he was somehow the head of the DEA as a psychopath. Also some of the scenes just don't really make any sense. The DEA does all sorts of weird things that just wouldn't happen in real life. I don't want to include spoilers so I won't go into detail.Now why did this movie make me feel weird in a way. The constant subtle hint of a sexual relationship between a child and a grown man (only in the directors cut). Portman is seen wearing very little clothing throughout the film and she even wears lingerie at one point. She also keeps telling Leon that she loves him during the film and Leon never really denies her feelings. He doesn't really give in either but he doesn't fully reject and it doesn't sit well with me. Portman was just so sexualized in this movie and I didn't like it, that's the main problem I have with it.

title: If you don't like this, we can't be friends.
content: Somehow I missed this incredible film when it came out. I was in college and studying pretty hard. Anyway....better late than never.This is a film that conveys how amazing humans are - from sadistic maniacs to tender hit men. The complexity of the behaviors, the abilities of the characters to make largely believable choices based on their moral codes, and some astonishing performances from some incredible actors make this a film you must like if we're ever going to see each other again.The principals give us some incredible performances. Jean Reno as Leon is astonishing. His ability to convey a million feelings with a blink of his eyes, a stiffening of his shoulders, or even the intake of breath make him someone I could watch in anything. I loved loved loved him in Ronin and this has only increased my love of the guy. I'm not gay but if I watch Leon enough, I might soon be! I will have to check out more of his work. His modesty, loyalty, decency, complexity, his tenderness and firmness with Mathilda (Natalie Portman), his steadfastness, and his courage make him one of my favorite movie characters in any film.I thought I wouldn't need to use any more superlatives for Natalie Portman having watched Heat about 50 times but she was younger in this film and she gives a performance with even more range than she showed in Heat. I'm happy to be able to see her work (even though I thought Black Swan was pretentious, predictable, melodramatic pablum). Her ability to convey anger, fearfulness, tenderness, confidence (I loved her peremptory dismissal of the four boys trying to protect their claim to neighborhood turf), and burgeoning sexuality (fortunately this part of the film doesn't quite take the film off course though I was worried for a second) while most definitely being a kid (she loves cartoons!!!) is amazing. Having said that, the best thing about Mathilda is her resilience. She is a survivor and this trait is Mathilda's baseline characteristic. Portman is just an incredibly gifted actress and her performance here is almost enough to leave me speechless.Danny Aiello is fantastic as Leon's loyal friend. He is a rock for Leon and asks no questions. He can always be trusted. Aiello conveys the sense of a man who cannot be shaken and is a true friend. He's probably heard it all and yet he's still there for his friend.Honestly, I thought Oldman was a bit over the top in his role. Obviously he is supposed to be out of control but I thought this was self-parodic, even for him.Luc Besson is never better at the helm and as a writer. His steady hand is much in evidence in keeping such a wild plot on pace and finding the emotional and moral centers of the film. The script is fantastic - a hit-man with a heart of gold, a precocious tweener, and a psychotic, crooked cop. Really, if you don't like this film, we can't be friends.

title: Excellent
content: My husband discovered this movie and urged me to watch it with him. We both believe it is one of the finest, most intriguing films ever made. Period! The performances by the entire cast are as amazing, as is the script. After watching it butchered by cuts and commercials on TV, we finally purchased a copy of our own. One of the wisest buys ever! Until then, we thought the title simply was "The Professional." Knowing Leon is the first part of the title is most satisfying. The character (and Reneau's performance) makes the name a requirement, which often is seen as the only title. Natalie Portman has gone on to make many other films, but this could still be her best effort. I'm sorry for anyone who has not seen this film.

title: Just perfect...
content: This is the first time I make a review so pardon me if you don't like it. The first time I saw this movie, I was just a little boy (not in the flesh but in mind... well you get the idea..). It was a Sunday afternoon and my father had just come back from our local movie rental place, and he said to me: "hey boy.. check this movie out...you are going to love it" of course, I didn't believe him but since I had nothing else to do, I gave it a try... two hours later I was shock yet relieve, sad yet happy and so emotional tired that I could't stand up from the couch.The acting, the writing, the photography, the music and the direction are to die for... even to kill for...jejeje.If I have to resume this film in one word, there's no other than: PerfectionWell, I not going to tell you any spoilers and ruin you the experience is going to be to watch this beautiful movie so...Do your self a favor, don't waste your time in any other rubbish and go see it NOW.

title: I fell in love
content: I have never felt what I felt when I watched that move. It's funny, there is action, and There is sad moments that made me cry the ending is just perfect I can't but wonder what Mathilda is doing now is she cleaning or did she finish school and got a regular job even tho I think she is cleaning.

title: One of the greatest movies ever made!
content: I first saw this movie when I was 8 years old and loved it. I've seen it countless times since and it only gets better after every viewing. From the excellent performances to the amazing directing, this movie has it all. Just the way the music ties perfectly to each scene and to the cinematography of the film is perfect. This is a perfect film.About the cinematography, it is some of the best I have ever seen, Besson is able to capture the city in such a way that it feels like a character in and of itself. The setting of the film is an extension of the films message. It is a depiction of hope and vengeance, while still managing to tell a tale of love and happiness, it is one of the greatest films put to screen.

title: Stylish and compelling to watch, but ultimately a very thin movie
content: Coming out the same year as Pulp Fiction, the Professional suffers from comparison. It remains a stylish violent drama that is compelling to watch. But at it's heart the movie is combo of standard revenge drama and standard grumpy old dude reluctantly takes younger girl under his wing- in this case to be an assassin. Natalie Portman's performance is eye catching and her sexualization at 14 is genuinely creepy.

title: Overrated
content: Natalie Portman is stilted and robotic delivering lines, though she occassionally shows flashes, Jean Reno is good, and Gary Oldman is fantastic.The plot is nonsensical and all over the place, the characters make mind-numbingly dumb decisions.Nothing in this film makes any sense from a character or plot perspective. It's also annoying to watch supposed tactical teams move like complete idiots on screen. It is very obvious that no one did 5 minutes of technical research before filming.There are flashes of brilliance in the movie, however. I just don't understand the love for this movie though. Outside of Gary Oldman, there is nothing that really stands out.

title: Best hit man movie ever
content: Luc Besson has created the most complete paid assassin film I've ever seen. Jean Reno plays the killer with a çombination of skill and daring and Natalie Portman is a Lolita- esque wannabe "cleaner" who Reno takes under his wing. Cleaner is the term used for a hit man and the premise of this movie is Reno training Portman how to kill efficiently without getting caught in the process.Nathalie(Portman) is a 12 year old girl who has witnessed the execution of her mother and father and is then instantly orphaned. Reno ends up taking her in and helping her avenge her parents deaths.What follows is heart stopping action and a tender love story which never crosses the line into pedophilia. The chemistry between Reno and Portman is magical and Gary Oldman is the perfect villain. I was just blown away by this thriller.

title: HOT TAKE: this is a great movie.
content: Vibrant, funny, emotionally affecting, effortlessly cool, and plenty exciting within its small world. However, is it just me, or is the way Portman is shot in this movie somewhat discomforting?

title: This Is One OF Those Rare Films Thats Gonna Disturb U For Long!
content: Well, i watched the movie only a few mins back and immediately i just felt like recommending this movie to all who haven't watched it yet. I had the movie for the past few months but i dint get any interest in watching it as i ain't familiar with anybody associated with the movie..But as i started watching, i was glued to it..its one of those well-made films that fail to reach to millions of people like me cos of not being appreciated with any awards.. the film deserved an Oscar (but sadly, not even a nomination)Only now, i knew the little girl was Nataile Portman..Wow, its really a fine acting from the actress and Jean's performance was highly commendable too..as the climax neared, i begin to hope for a happy ending but the director chose reality instead.. now this climax is one dat am gonna think for a while and console myself that its just a movie.. :(Great piece of work really..don't waste ur time reading these re- views..watch it as soon as possible..

title: My second favourite film
content: Leon the professional is my second favourite film. I absolutely love it. This film ticks all the boxes for me, it has drama, violence, emotion, thrills, romance, humour and much more. The only film that tops it for me is The Shawshank Redemption (click my name above to see my review on that) so therefore for me it beats the likes of my other favourites like The Godfather and Schindlers list. One of the main reason this film is so great is because of Natalie Portmans amazing acting in it, she managed to capture angry, suicidal, vengeful side of Mathilda but also the loving more caring side of her, not many grown up actors/actresses can do that let alone a kid.In conclusion I'd say this is a film that all audiences can watch and enjoy.

title: Léon - the best assassin film ever made
content: The Reno/Besson team meets once again for one of the best films of the decade, and certainly the best assassin film made.  The casting is spot on, with all 3 stars giving moving and often powerful performances.  Reno is perfect as the quiet assassin, both gentle yet ruthless, Natalie Portman is the finest child actor I have ever seen and Gary Oldman (who is English and not American as indicated in other reports!) produces a stunning performance as one of the most terrifying movie villains ever portrayed.Not to be missed. If you haven't seen this film yet, beg, borrow or steal to do so (or you could just buy one I suppose), you will not regret it.  Fans of The Godfather et al should especially enjoy this, despite having a different atmosphere.

title: How is the top 250?
content: Let me start of by saying this movie is not bad!Leon is very entertaining and original. Has some dull spots, but amazingly well written and well acted out characters. This is a GOOD movie. I stress the word GOOD. It is not GREAT. I could understand and relate to someone who found it GREAT. But in now way what so ever is this a top 250 ever and BY GOD IT IS NOT A TOP 50!!! There must be something I was missing. I watched a really cool action film that was better than the rest due to its intricately woven characters and its original storyline. That does not mean its better than DIE HARD and YES it falls in the exact same genre and YES I just compared the two. Overall cool cool cool flick, definitely watch to entertain yourself, but CMON TOP 50? Please this just goes to show the rediculousness of IMDb ratings nowadays... and just so everyone knows I am not bashing this movie it is just sorely overrated on here so I had to voice myself. As my Comcast Cable Company rated it so wisely 2/4 stars! OUCH! sry fans but its the truth! Hey I think its better than 5/10 stars though!... but nothing over a 7 please.

title: Good movie, still today. Mathilda character did not age well. Ughhhh
content: I was never quite sure whether I had watched this as a teen or at least parts of it. So Christmas was a good opportunity for a full-on action movie and nothing felt familiar at all, so I guess I just didn't see it. Maybe.It starts very strong, with an amazing action sequence and I was a bit frustrated that I couldn't understand how on earth he did it. Towards the end we are shown a little bit more of his special techniques. However, after that we get to learn more about Leon and we find out he has a very unusual backstory, and that despite his very precise and specific and razor-sharp skills, he is not the smartest tool in the shed in a lot of other ways. And he has been molded and taught all these things by his manager/handler. Which was a little disappointing if I'm honest , but maybe that's just me. His deadpan looks and stares do work very well though, especially in relation to Mathilda. As for young Mathilda, I was put off by the disturbing Lolita vibes and thankfully Leon does not respond, but it is a little uncomfortable to watch. Natalie Portman did great of course, but Luc Besson, you are one sick individual to have written her that way.It was a very entertaining movie, despite all that and the need to suspend your disbelief with the level of police corruption and violence, but it's not one of the great movies for me. It is good though, still today. There is a lot of originality to it, especially when compared to the absolutely mediocre churn out of action movies these days.

title: Matilda is cute
content: Leon (Jean Reno) who is a professional killer opens the heart little by little to Matilda (Natalie Portman), the girl who aims at a professional killer for the revenge which had the younger brother killed. And Leon comes to have feeling. This movie contains all the elements have scenes with tension, calm scene, and the scene laughable. An action scene is impressive. Camera work is also wonderful. Fusion of showy action and true love calls big impression for the last scene. Even when you dislike an action film, since this work has the contents, I think that it is interesting for everyone. I was very impressed with the figure that Matilda is endure the sadness. Natalie's overwhelming presence of that time 13 years old is wonderful. Leon is good at teaching about how to use a weapon. However, he can't teach the other thing very well. I think this gap is one of a highlight.

title: Unforgettable
content: Almost 30 years later, this film is just as good as it was then. And it's still as good after 5 showings than it was at the first. Not many movies can do that.Natalie Portman is extraordinary here. One of the very best child acting ever seen.Gary Oldman gets his best role here imo. Over the top but that's what the character required. And he takes so much fun playing that role. He really steals the scenes he's in. Brilliant.Together with The big blue (Le Grand Bleu), Leon provides Jean Reno with his best role. Reno is not a great actor but he gives his best here and is perfect for the role. He succeeds in making Leon human and touching. And such a great chemistry with Portman!Somes scenes are very emotional, heartbreaking even, others are extremely violent. It's fast paced. The music is excellent.Hugely enjoyable, one of the best movies ever. It's much more than a mere action movie.

title: This is from Mathilda....a beautiful, entertaining film with heart.
content: Its nice to see another of my personal favorites score so highly with IMDb reviewers! The professional is about a hit-man Leon (Jean Reno) who befriends young Mathilda (Natalie Portman) after her family is murdered. Mathilda decides she wants revenge and insists Leon teach her how to "clean". A very touching relationship then develops between the two which is at the center of this amazing film. I really love this movie!I need to comment on the actors here. This is the first time I saw Ms. Portman on film was captivated by her from the first time I saw The Professional (and have been ever since in 'Beautiful girls', V for vendetta,'Black Swan' etc). Mathilda has had a tough life, her father and older sister were both abusive to her and her step-mother didn't seem to care. She hated the school she attended and liked to hang out on the stairway of her apartment building sneaking cigarettes. Portman plays her as vulnerable, distressed yet strong and endearing...and totally believable the whole way.Then there's Gary Oldman, who in my opinion is absolutely the finest character actor in movies over the last 20 years or so. I've never seen him give a bad performance (he was especially great in the 1990 film "State of Grace"). Oldman here delivers what may be his best performance ever as the sleazy, psychotic DEA agent Stansfield. We watch him chew on his mysterious pills while cracking his neck and listen as he obsesses with Beethoven and think...wow! this is one of the creepiest characters ever put on film. During the climactic scene he tells an assistant to "send me everyone" and the assistant incredulously asks "everyone?" to which Stansfield chillingly screams "EVERYONE!!"...we get the point, the guy is nuts but has power...and cops show up in droves.I don't mean to underrate Reno's performance here, he is quietly brilliant, the best I've ever seen of him to date. Leon doesn't have a whole lot of dialog as the professional, and thats by design as the character is Italian and we presume he hasn't been in the United States for long and doesn't know a whole lot of English. Reno is perfect in the role, and when he delivers that signature line I quoted above..."this is from Mathilda"...it packs a powerful and emotional punch. It's a truly great payoff scene.This is not necessarily a movie with a happy ending, but this isn't meant to be a feel-good movie, it's bigger than that. However, it IS very satisfying and a nice symbolic scene at the end on the lawn of Mathilda's new school ties it all up very nicely. If you are choking back tears, you are not alone.Real nice song by Sting "shape of my heart" over the closing credits caps it off..Enjoy.

title: This S*** was Wild Son!!!
content: May have spoilers, but nothing to serious, like describing a scene. I only talk about the relationship with the two main characters.Well I wasn't going to say much but if my review isn't long enough I can't submit it. But to start off saying that this was a great film. One of my favorite movies. I had no idea that this movie would be so great. Never seeing any clip or preview of this movie, I didn't expect this movie to be such a good drama, and all the action came to be a big surprise for me. The only thing I knew was the relationship between Leon and Metilda. And personally I didn't want to see it because I thought, that what they did together would be to graphic(sexually). Though I was dead wrong, they never go overboard with those two relationship.Right from the start of the movie I knew I was going to love it. All the main characters performances were perfect! Not much else to say but that everyone should see this movie!!!

title: Natalie Portman was brilliant but some plot-driven decisions seemed off to me
content: My biggest take from this movie is that young Natalie Portman was a badass. I imagine a lot of people might find Mathilda's character as uncomforting but seeing as she came from a troubling family, most likely with no friends, her character arc makes a lot of sense for me. To some extent, she even reminded me of Wan-Chu, the disturbed girl from Dangerous Encounters of the First Kind (1980), both by looks and violent tendencies. Of course, she's not as destructive and might be viewed as a watered-down version of Wan-Chu, but she definitely wasn't boring and was badass enough for my taste. For me, these kinds of disturbing and troubled characters always seemed more entertaining than your average "walk-in-the-park" characters.Even though the plot is action-driven with a great premise - a young pre-teen girl teaming up with a hitman after an unfortunate demise of her whole family - this movie didn't really go too well with me. I don't know whether it's the lack of the X-factor that would push me over the hump of excitement or the fact that Gary Oldman's character was the only one that couldn't be viewed as just a redshirt character. The movie was exciting to some extent but the over-the-top plot was a bit of a turn-off for me. The ending was emotional but the shootout was a bit ridiculous. I know Leon is viewed as a professional and a threat but sending 200 guys just for him and the way it went down just didn't click with me.Besides what I mentioned already, I'd like to say that the violent scenes are top-notch and the romance, whether disturbing or not, was cute and kind of shows how easy it is to dream for girls of that age. I don't think there's anything wrong with the cast and their talent, it was just the key plot moment weren't as enjoyable as they could have been. If rating just the portion of the movie before Mathilda went off to the DEA building, I'd rate it way higher, or even if the finale of the movie took place by Leon saving Mathilda from Gary Oldman's character, I'd think the scenery would be greater to end things off.

title: Truly superb
content: So different from the run of the mill action movies. Watchable again and again. Superbly directed and acted. Jean Reno, Natalie Portman and Gary Oldman deliver stunning performances. The story is superb. A truly unique film.

title: One of my all-time favorite movies
content: I first saw this in a theater in Paducah, Kentucky when it was released in 1994. I paid the full admission, but I was so taken with the film that I went back two nights later and paid full price to watch it again. I have viewed the American version numerous times on DVD and plan to own one of the extended versions soon.Jean Reno is great in his custom-tailored role as Leon, the Italian hit-man with a French accent.What can I say about Natalie Portman as Mathilda? If this little girl doesn't break your heart, you'd better check to be sure you still one.Gary Oldman demonstrates that he is one of the finest actors with his over-the-top portrayal of drug-crazed DEA Agent Norman Stansfield. It has been said better by other writers, but Oldman disappears inside of each character he plays. Most of the people to whom I have shown this film insist that they have never seen Oldman in any movie until I start listing some of his roles. "Oh yeah, I saw that movie. Is that the guy who..."Oldman's acting is like your clothing. If people notice your clothes, you're probably overdressed. With Gary Oldman, you can't tell that he's acting.

title: An absolute classic.
content: Luc Besson brings an impossible relationship between a cold-blooded assassin and a 12-year old orphaned girl to reality in this one. Natalie Portman's screen debut in a leading role was absolutely special. Definitely one of the best performances of any child actor in film history, if not the best. There isn't a young actress out there that could've played that role as effectively as Portman. The emotion she's able to summon from when she's looking for Leon to open the door after her family's been shot, to the entertaining charades game, to the intense scene with Stansfield in the bathroom, truly amazing. You can't help but feel empathy for her character. Vintage Gary Oldman playing the bad guy as the corrupt DEA officer, one of his best performances as an actor. His over the top nature made the film even more entertaining.Flat out one of the best movies of all time. Please watch the extended director's cut and not the theatrical version!

title: A Beautiful Modern Crime Tale....
content: Just finished watching this movie and It was a very nice experience. Obviously a very well made movie which holds your interest from beginning to credits. Natalie Portman is such a surprise, Hit Girl (Kick Ass) seems like a copy of her character. The Original score, Editing, Performances, Direction and every aspect of the movie is so well that its hard to look for negative points.The Movies portrays Action/Crime/Emotions wonderfully.And its not over violent nor fake (like in todays Hollywood flicks) the movie is authentic.I have to agree that it was Snubbed by all major Awards.I definitely will recommend this to every one, Its entertaining, touching and a very nice 128 minute experience.

title: Carefully composed action drama that has a big heart
content: The innocence of the two protagonists here, despite one being a killer, is what makes this movie. Leon is a very simple man from a poor background in Sicily, and although highly disciplined, comes across as very honest and caring. The slightly precocious Matilda is equally enigmatic, from a troubled background she is continually forced to rise above. Their relationship leaps off the screen from perfect performances, tugging our heartstrings. Gary Oldman also gives a no holds barred performance to create a supremely twisted character. It all has the quaintness of good child/adult drama whilst sending out regular sparks from orchestrated violence, a tough act to follow.

title: Professional
content: Luc Besson doesn't hold any record in my book for credible filmmaking. Nikita was an interesting take on an unconventional subject (or an unconventional take on a redundant subject, you decide), The Fifth Element was not as good as people will profess, and The Messenger got too weighted down.  Nonetheless, Leon gets marks in my book due to the following characteristics.1) Jean Reno: since this movie, he has been typecast by Hollywood time and time again whether in Godzilla, Ronin, or Mission: Impossible.  It's as if the script calls for "french or other foreign looking guy who looks like he can kick ass", they call him.  Either way, Besson uses the role and the character of Leon around him as opposed to making Reno fit a mold.  Smart idea.2) Gary Oldman: yet another guy commonly typecast into villain roles, Oldman goes about hammering the anvil with his character and drawing the most attention to himself.  Best line: "Bring me everyone." "Whadaya mean 'everyone'?"  "EVERYONE!"  Sometimes I wonder if he will ever get a decent role.  The Fifth Element was too much in the vein of Saturday Morning Cartoons and less out of seriousness.3) Natalie Portman:  as far as I am concerned, Natalie is currently a slave to the promotional department at Lucasfilm.  Until she gets out of that money pit, I will consider this her best performance.  Considering the subject at hand and the level of involvement on her character's part, this is light-years beyond any OO7 flick.4) Shifty editing: the editing is superb and complements with Besson's very European style of film.  Not once did I get the idea that a scene was unnecessary or drawn out longer than it should have.  Kudos to Sylvie Landra.Overall, an action movie less in the vein of comic books and more with pulp writing.  Better than the other blockbuster garbage of 1994.  4 out of 5 stars.

title: An all time classic. A simple story about a very non-simple situation.
content: Jean Reno plays the titular character – regardless of the name on the spine of the DVD – he is both Leon and the Professional. A quiet intense man who lives a solitary existence of discipline and ritual, honing his skills as an assassin that leaves no trace and carries out his work cleanly and perfectly, a man with only two parameters to his work: 'No women. No kids.' When the family that lives next door in his modest apartment building is butchered by corrupt police after a drug deal gone wrong, leaving only 11 year old Mathilda (Natalie Portman), Leon has virtually no choice but to literally take her in, lest he break his own rules through deliberate inaction.In the days and weeks that follow, impressionable Mathilda – who feels she is wise beyond her years – comes to realise the enormity of her situation. This is only magnified when she learns of Leon's true occupation. Of course being no more than a kid, Mathilda hardly finds this news abhorrent, but decides that she wishes to learn the ropes of what Leon refers to as 'cleaning'.This leads to a strange new existence for Leon, he cannot force pre-teen Mathilda out into the real world, but allowing her to remain compromises his disciplined existence. The mismatched duo settle in to a 'Daddy / Daughter' relationship, with Mathilda remaining home while Leon heads off to 'work', the issue rapidly becomes that Mathilda rapidly starts seeing Leon as less of a Father figure, and more of a crush Seeing that Mathilda is so headstrong, determined and convincing, and that Leon is if anything slightly child-like and has been shielded from normal human relationships, Leon ultimately yields a little and tentatively commits to basic training; something his employer Tony (Danny Aiello) is rightfully doubtful of.Regardless of suitability or basic ethics, the Leon / Mathilda relationship evolves into a strange partnership, and bringing your (pseudo) daughter to work days take on strange and uncomfortable significance. As Mathilda develops new skills and confidences unbecoming of her fragile years it is more and more evident that her ultimate intent is to avenge the deaths of her family Which brings us to Mr Gary Oldman and his role as corrupt cop Stansfield.Stansfield works for the Drug Enforcement Agency in the police force, however his entire unit is entirely crooked. Oldman toes the fine line between over the top intensity and cartoonishness well for the most part, and I guess if you are looking to forgive some of his antics you could always point to the green and yellow capsules that he takes prior to his more 'memorable' sequences.What is undeniable is that the and inescapable routine that the reserved and measured Leon is bound by is an effective counterpoint to the haphazard and impetuous existence of Stansfield. Having initially innocent Mathilda embroiled between these ying and yang characters provides the film with a centre, and the inevitable feeling that all three characters will find themselves in the same place at the same time.Leon is full of long low key scenes with equally subtle background music, 90% of the dialogue is between Mathilda and Leon – with a good two thirds of each conversation dominated by the precocious child. These scenes are punctuated by sudden dramatic scenes of violence, especially as the film nears its conclusion and Mathilda finally learns that there are some things that kids shouldn't be subjected to regardless of how 'ready' they think they are.Leon: The Professional was directed and written by Luc Besson, who has managed to leave his fingerprints on several essential action flicks from the last couple decades, Taken, Kiss of the Dragon, The Transporter and Unleashed included. Leon seems to be quite a personal work, and while some of the other works listed are very good and worth checking out, in my mind Leon: The Professional stands head and shoulders above them all.This film granted both Gary Oldman and Jean Reno eternal credibility to a generation of young film-goers, and helped launch the career of Natalie Portman. For a moment it almost made me want to buy a skull cap Now nearly two decades on I am at odds with the more 'risky' scenes that further the on the job training and 'romantic' aspects of the storyline. I am by no means decrying their inclusion as being abhorrent or immoral, but I similarly don't really see them adding much to what was already an amazing and essential film.Final Rating – 9 / 10. A simple story about a very non-simple situation, Leon remains an all time classic.

title: Guns and a few glasses of milk.
content: Leon lovingly cares for plants. He watches vintage romantic musicals, and he has a sense of humour. Hardly the traits of an assassin, wouldn't you agree?Leon is a professional hitman who lives in an ordinary apartment building. His next-door neigbour is an abusive father, who has been stealing cocaine. When DEA boss Stansfield (Gary Oldman) discovers he has been stealing, he cold-bloodedly murders his family. 12-year old Mathilda - who was out shopping - escapes the massacre. On her return, she notices the killings and finds shelter at Leon's apartment.With nowhere to go, and wanting to avenge Stansfield, she asks Leon to teach her to become a 'cleaner' - or assassin. Reluctant at first, Leon agrees. And so an unlikely friendship develops between Leon and Mathilda. It is a well written script, and the film has a great score.I remember seeing 'Leon: The Professional' in theatres back in 1994 when it was released, and thinking it was a bit boring. I was very young at the time and watched it now again as an adult. Having learnt life's lessons, the film definitely had a much greater appeal to me now than it did when I was a youngster. Still, there were moments when it felt the film dragged too much. I understand it was necessary to establish a relationship between the lead characters (no, not as in an intimate relationship, thank goodness!) so we could understand them and their situation better.Dialogue throughout the movie hinted at what the outcome might have been, and it was indeed so. 'Leon: The Professional' is a stylish drama which doesn't offer much in the form of action. This is mostly a character-driven movie. The performances are absolutely fantastic. Gary Oldman, especially, is brilliant as always. This was a career-defining part for Natalie Portman, and the film that propelled Jean Reno to international stardom.

title: Saw the Extended Director's Cut
content: Sorry, I didn't get the appeal!Going in, I expected a nail-biting action thriller, but it turned out to be a trivial drama in which a contentious relationship between a 12-year-old child and a middle-aged man is portrayed as the norm, which is strange and quite distasteful to some extent.Even if I ignore the problematic aspects of the script, it still doesn't seem to make an impact. The action is well shot, and the direction isn't half bad, but it is the pacing that ultimately marred the efficacy and momentum of the narration and robbed me of my enjoyment.That being said, I still appreciate the actors for what they have done here. Portman did great; for an 11 year old (she was at that time) child artist, she did a fine job. So did Jean Reno with his laid-back, expressionless role of Leon, but for me, it was Oldman who took the limelight. He was freaking amazing; I wish he had more screen time. I think the film needed more Gary Oldman!

title: Characterised by 1 performance
content: It's a good movie, without doubt, yet I cant help but feel that the cult following that IMDb has garnered is the cause for it having such a high rating. I mean it shouldn't be in the top 40 (or so) films of all time list.After watching Leon I felt rather hard done by, yes the review I've given is good and it's deserved but it can hardly be considered a masterpiece. To satisfy curiosity I suggest it's worth the watch, if only for another spellbinding turn by undoubtedly the greatest English actor of his generation. Not only has Gary Oldman set the benchmark for sociopathic villains, but his touch is so feather light that the eccentricities of each individual movement are as delightfully entrancing as they are wickedly sickening. Yes, admittedly my admiration for the man led me to write this review but only because I feel it important to tell others that this is one of his best performances to date and that it prevents this movie from being forgotten.I watched the film after seeing a 'Top Ten Gary Oldman Performances' video on the old youtube thingymajigg ('watchmojo' is a very interesting channel, go on... check it out.) and this has led me to scouring the internet for different films involving this guy, and honestly, and fairly upsettingly, I can't think of a better way I could've spent my time. In my, not too sought after opinion, he is the greatest actor I've ever seen and I repeatedly tell my friends ( and I know I don't sound like a guy who has any, but I'm fairly certain that they can be counted as friends ( don't ask them in case I'm wrong )) to study the man in great detail. I mean, they hadn't even heard of him. Anyway, in all honesty, this review was supposed to be serious but I fear I'm losing my way. So on we go...The performance of Reno is sturdy as is the support of the majority of the cast; obviously the use of a child acting doesn't fail to annoy, even though the girl in question went on to reach stardom (didn't see that coming). I'm not an expert in direction so I'm not in a place to comment on Besson's job, but he's created an enjoyable film that certainly breaches the norm, so top marks there. I don't know what to make of the French, this film points in their favour though.I think this conclusion gives me an excuse to compliment G.O. so I will. All I'll say is that if you have the intention/hope/dream of going into acting, or simply just admire this strand of entertainment: this guy's the man to watch.Sorry for going on, anyway I liked it... I suggest giving it a go.

title: brilliant. absolutely brilliant.

I'm surprised this never won any Oscars or Golden Globes. This is a film that most certainly deserves its 'Cult Classic' label, and is a movie that should be a trailblazer for the genre.

title: Brilliant, powerful story of revenge...and belonging
content: Brilliant, powerful story of revenge...and belonging.Leon (played by Jean Reno) lives in New York and is a professional hit-man. One of his neighbours, Mathilda (Natalie Portman), is a 12- year old girl with family problems, one of which is that her father is a petty criminal. One day, a drug kingpin, Stansfield (Gary Oldman), kills her entire family due to something her father did. Mathilda turns to Leon for help...and revenge.Excellent crime drama. Good plot, meticulously set out and executed. Good action scenes too. Not just an action-drama though - there is also an emotional aspect to the movie, and a theme of setting down roots and belonging somewhere.Solid work by Jean Reno and Natalie Portman (12 years old and in her first movie) in the lead roles. Both these performances are eclipsed, however, by an amazing performance by Gary Oldman as the villain. Pure over-the-top, menacing, evil, bizarre genius of a performance by him. The only disappointment of this movie is that Oldman did not have more screen time.

title: Ick!
content: I'll try not to be too gratuitously abusive about this film, but considering the astounding amount of uncritical, even hysterical, raves it has received from viewers, I feel like I have to swat it down a peg or two.  Any fairly flashy film with a lot of guns, explosions, death and destruction is bound to excite a large number of moviegoers.  I used to think this is more of an American thing, but the comments from overseas seem to contradict that old cliche.  Bad taste is universal, it seems.  Still, the ardent praise of its plot and characterizations astonish me, as these elements of the film left me with a creepy, vaguely dirty impression of the film.  Enthusiasts for the film defend its morality, and suggest that any hint of sexual tension between Leon and young Mathilda is in the mind of the viewer.  However, the fact that Mathilda is always dressed in a sort of provocative, gothic punk/slut attire, and the fact that she openly hints to a hotel clerk that she and Leon are having sex (I know, they aren't) suggests that the filmmakers would like us to be thinking about the possibility of it, even if it is not portrayed.  in a way, a straightforward sex exploitation film is more honest that this kind of hypocrisy.  As for Leon -- are we supposed to love this guy?  Leon is a hit man.  What's a hit man but a specific variety of serial murderer?  We're supposed to like him because he is kind to children and houseplants?  Jame Gumb loves his little dog, but that doesn't make him any more cuddly (see "Silence of the Lambs, a REALLY good film). so the emotionally damaged kid finds out that her new father figure is a paid killer, calmly says "cool" (yuck!), and Leon proceeds to instruct her in the noble profession of killing people for money.  but the killer has scruples after all!  "No women or kids" he says.  What a saint!  Are we to assume Leon knows for a fact that the world will be a better place without the men he's being paid to kill?  Sort of like the evil twin of Clarence, the angel in "It's a Wonderful Life."  Aren't the men he kills without even knowing them somebody's children too?  Might there be women and children who will be hurt by their assassination?  Aren't women sometimes evil too?  And then we're supposed to feel Leon's basic human goodness because he asks Mathilda not to swear so much, even though he has taught her how to kill people without thinking too much about it.  Is this all some kind of subtle satire?  If so, I think it's a bit too subtle for most people, including myself.  If it's meant to be taken seriously -- well, I just can't think of it as anything but some sort of moral idiocy.  I take nothing away from this film cinematically.  It's a great-looking film, but to me it's just plain creepy and disturbing.  Besson's "Fifth Element" was a lot more enjoyable to me, both as eye candy and as entertainment.  Sorry to rain on the parade.

While I enjoyed both of those movies immensely, I hated the dialogue, especially between her and Anakin).I saw the uncut version, and from what I've read, the US cut ("The Professional") removes all of the tenderness between Leon and Matilda. Squeemish MPAA viewers who don't like the relationship between Leon and Matilda removed the film's most important parts (and for worried viewers out there- don't worry, nothing "happens", but their love is very well played, and quite believable).So anyway- see this movie, but the uncut version, not the US cut. It is one of my all-time favorites (on my top 10), and establishes Luc Besson as one of my favorite directors. If you haven't, also see The Fifth Element, and La Femme Nikita.10/10 - superb.
