title: A Masterpiece of an Action/Drama Film Perfectly Executed
content: With the brilliant acting of Jean Reno and a young Natalie Portman, and with the brilliant direction of Luc Besson, Léon: The Professional is sure to please any action fanatic or drama lover. From the opening scene of this movie, you can tell that every take was thought out and every take has a unique mood. Léon: the Professional isn't without its flaws, however, which I will outline later in the review.One aspect that Besson really put his back into was the characters, and it shows. A young Natalie Portman plays Mathilda, a down on her luck kid who craves revenge and a parental figure to guide her through a tough part of her life. Léon, played by Jean Reno, truly is the star of this film. Léon is a notorious Italian assassin who travels on a path of self discovery throughout this whole film. With every word that Léon speaks you can sense a deep and daring combination of optimism, pessimism, and darkness. Though he is a rather quiet character, just the tone in Léon's voice shows that he is a true striking mafia man. Finally, the villain in this film, played by Gary Oldman, is a devious character. As the film progresses, your hate for him builds up inside. My one issue with Oldman's character, however, is that you cannot relate to him. All good villains should have a reason for what they are doing and something in common with the protagonist, in this case Léon. This was not present in Oldman's character. Aside from this one minor flaw, great, realistic but still awesome characters made this film what it is.As great as the characters are, when I think of this movie I will always first think of its incredible score, composed by John Altman. Every step of the way the score perfectly accompanies the mood of the scene. It is a perfect example of how symphony music doesn't just appeal to the wide arrange of 80 year old's throughout the world, but can also appeal to many more people if executed correctly, which it was.As my title would suggest, Léon can't be fit into one genre, but many. The action aspect of this film is incredible. With near complete use of practical effects and Besson's history in directing great action films, you really marvel at how certain scene's were created (particularly the end of act three, like holy crap!). The drama and emotional conflict in this film is also substantial. You can understand and relate to many of the characters in this movie, and really feel what they are feeling for a lot of the film (aside from the large number of people in this film that get shot, that would hurt like hell and as a result Besson didn't include that aspect for viewers). There is also a strange feeling of romance in this film, but that gets into spoiler territory so I should shut up!One slight issue that I have always had in this film is not what is present, but what is not, for the majority of the film. Unlike most other films, my favorite moment in Léon: the Professional is the first act. There is a deep feeling of darkness and actual fear throughout the whole first act. You get the horrendous feeling that something awful will happen, and it does. I would've liked to see that feeling of darkness a bit more throughout the film. Not the whole time, but I think that feeling could have added a lot to a few scenes.In conclusion, Léon the Professional is a gorgeous, musical, grim, witty, and brilliantly put together film. For this reason it deserves an A- (8.3/10).

title: A Rare Treat
content: At first when I heard about the plot to this, I thought it will not work. A young teenager girl being looked after by her neighbour hitman, since her whole family is completely massacred by a bent copper.It sounded like it was going to be a buddy movie, one of those where everyone will live very happily. But when I watch this, I was so wrong. It is one of those movies which will always remain as one of my favorites, ranked with Pulp Fiction and Reservoir Dogs. This movie is easily intertwined both funny scenes between the girl and the hitman, the graphic violence, and the great acting by Jean Reno, Natalie Portman and Gary Oldman and producd with one the finest movies ever.

title: Cult status is well deserved
content: Mathilda (Natalie Portman), a 12 year old girl, sees her family murdered by Stanfield (Gary Oldman) and his gang, and is taken by Léon (Jean Reno), a professional hit-man that teaches her the trade.I know that cinema, has an art form, may serve to break the boundaries of reality, but I like to see some plausibility in movies and stories; I say this 'cause the action scenes are, as usual, exaggerated and unrealistic, mainly at the beginning of the movie. But as it progresses, we get to know the characters and are plunged into their world due to first-class acting and the strange relation Léon and Mathilda develop. The camera work of Luc Besson is very interesting and well thought out, greatly enhancing the quality of the movie.Is it worth watching? Definitely! Its cult status is well deserved.

title: Inspired by "Home Alone"
content: Both "Leon" and "Home Alone" contain plot elements involving a young child doing things one would find not very likely to happen, or even remotely possible. "Home Alone" of course was a comedy, so you can laugh at the silliness of it while realizing all along that it's preposterous. But does that idea still work in a film you are supposed to take seriously?Plot In a Nutshell: A young girl left orphaned by a drug hit on her family is taken in and mentored by her next door neighbor, who happens to be a lethal assassin.Why I rated it a '6': Because the plot is as silly as it sounds. It actually DOES sound like a comedy, doesn't it? Sadly, it's not. And it's all the worse for it. Who really thinks a loner hitman would do this? How about bringing the girl to an orphanage? Or Child Services in the city? Hello? Well, no, because then you wouldn't have a movie. But does anyone really think an actual contract killer would take in a little girl, and not only that, but begin to train her in the ways of an assassin? Count me out. This isn't compelling theater. It's fantasy all the way, and not very riveting at that. Not for a second did I find myself invested in this plotline. I kept thinking "if I was a hitman, would I do this?" and the answer kept coming back "Uh, no you would not." So the film's story lost me very early on, and it could not get me back. The fact that this unrealistic fantasy (yet set in the real world) is currently #31 on the IMDb Top 250 is pretty hilarious. For all the wrong reasons of course.Roger and me: In his 1994 review Roger Ebert gave this film 2.5/4 stars, calling it "a romantic fantasy, not a realistic crime picture," and he was right on the money. Fanboys take note.6/10. Good cinematography and acting, but an extremely unlikely and unrealistic plot makes this a one-and-done film. Would I watch again (Y/N)?: Nope.

title: Leon, The Professional
content: The measured lifestyle of the killer was turned off in one day, after in his door the 12 years old girl was knocked. He knew, how it would be ending, but nevertheless has let the girl. Small Matilda had no place to go, after all her family was killed by the corrupted policemen. The little girl has only one desire to revenge for the little brother who was killed by people of Stensfild. Living with Leon she understands that has fallen in love to him. Mathilda, a twelve-year old New York girl, is living an undesirable life among her half-family. Her father stores drugs for two-faced cop Norman Stansfield. Only her little brother keeps Mathilda from breaking apart. One day, Stansfield and his team take cruel revenge on her father for stretching the drugs a little, thus killing the whole family. Only Mathilda, who was out shopping, survives by finding shelter in Leons apartment in the moment of highest need. Soon, she finds out about the strange neighborers unusual profession — killing — and desperately seeks his help in taking revenge for her little brother. Leon, who is completely unexperienced in fatherly tasks, and in friendships, does his best to keep Mathilda out of trouble — unsuccessfully. Now, the conflict between a killer, who slowly discovers his abilities to live, to feel, to love and a corrupt police officer, who does anything in his might to get rid of an eye witness, arises to unmeasurable proportions — all for the sake of a little twelve-year old girl, who has nearly nothing to lose.

title: A gangster's fairytale
content: So much can be said about this movie. It is really a wild guess that worked out brilliantly to let a kid play a leading role in a gangster movie. Nathalie Portman's debut is to thank for the truly magnificent believability she gives to her role. Jean Reno, Danny Aiello are the other masters at work. Gary Oldman however plays the part of his life. Nothing is scarier than a lunatic who smiles at you. And he plays the part of the mentally deranged corrupt criminal so well that it is a joy to watch again and again.Seen "Leon" 10 times or more now and I keep loving it. Every time I think now I have seen it all, but it stays thrilling till the very end. And endearing. How does director Luc Besson do that? How does he make a serial killer so likeable?If I would just tell the story you wouldnt believe me. Objectively speaking this script makes no sense. None. Even a character in the movie who has to explain what has happened isnt believed. A hitman for the mob gets befriended with a young girl. That's the story in a nutshell. But that doesnt come close to what really happened. The story presented in a nutshell sounds sweet, doesnt it? But there are massive amounts of assasinations that take place in between scenes.How can that be sweet? But it can be, because the violence in "Leon" is presented as if it were a game of playing cowboys and indians. That "funny" tarantino kind of violence in "Leon" is produced by a frenchman who came to America: director Luc Besson. This man has an odd talent: he mixes humor and childlike innocence on the one hand with brutal violence on the other hand. And somehow it works. The violence is cartoonlike and funny, but still suspensefull and realistic. Just as in Quentin Tarantino's work. You can laugh about the violent crimes in "Pulp Fiction" but you still take Samuel L. Jackson seriously.Oh I could go on and on about this movie. Never felt a bigger urge to write about so many different aspects in a review as with "Leon". Because it is extraordinary unique in script and excecution by the director. I think that "Leon" is Luc Besson's masterpiece. Brilliantly directed. Brilliantly performed. And a script that is bonkers but still so believable and endearing thanks to those magnificent young acting talents that came together in this fabulous gangster's fairytale!

title: Luc Besson: The Professional!
content: This film, Leon the Professional, is a very strong and powerful film. It's thought-provoking, but emotional. What I liked about this film the most is how we truly feel for the characters. The scenes that we got to know these characters are great since we learn what kind of people they are. I loved how they try to play out the relationship between Leon and his protégé, Mathilda.Luc Besson's film, which is his first American film, is about a hit-man named Leon who reluctantly takes in a girl whose family just got murdered by a corrupt DEA agent and his cronies. Wishing for revenge, Mathilda is tutored on how to kill in order for her to unleash her anger.The acting is very good. Jean Reno is very convincing as Leon and after watching this film, I believe this is his signature film. Making her film debut, Natalie Portman is great and really brings substance to her 12-year-old self. Finally, Gary Oldman is always amazing and he delivers one of his best performances. I love him as a villain and his Beethoven-loving character broadens him yet again.Overall, this is a great film that packs a punch and delivers the goods. One would expect this to be an action or gangster film, but it's more of a character study with more subtle moments. Not to say that there isn't any hardcore action, but the emotional punch this movie gives is what gives this film a heart. I rate this film 10/10.

title: A great action movie with a heart.
content: Deliriously corrupt DEA agents, a murderously vengeful 12 year-old kid who's fond of smoking, and a coldly-efficient killer who has more of a heart than he would like to think. These are the ingredients of Léon: The Professional, and they combine to make quite the tasty dish.This is definitely an action movie, but it's the non-action parts that make it so memorable. Most of them are between Léon and Mathilda. When he first passes her on the stairs with her cigarette and bruises, or when he takes her up on the roof overlooking Central Park for her first real lesson. Scenes like these add a real emotional gravity to the movie, which 75% of action flicks either don't even bother with, or give a half-hearted attempt at, at best. A lot of people may focus on only the violent or seemingly exploitative aspects of the film, but that means that they're missing out on something much deeper.As for flaws, Gary Oldman takes over-acting to a whole new level in this movie. Occasionally, that kind of thing is okay (or even a plus), but not here. This isn't The Fifth Element. He was too wacky to feel sinister or dangerous. Other than that, this is a fantastic movie that is worth adding to anyone's collection.

title: A witty film
content: A great and witty film about how a hitman really might be.  A hitman really would kill without emotion, just doing his job.  Great plot combined with great acting, with some brutal, but not too bad, violence.  The ending is not disappointing, and I thought that the film was very good.  Jean Reno's acting performance is fine, as is the girl who played Mathilda, and Gary Oldman is OK.  The beginning of the film is great, where he turns up at a house, and moves without sound, and kills without remorse.  A good film experience that I recommend.

title: Disturbing yet enthralling
content: This film drives you to question yourself and makes you deeply uncomfortable along the way, especially in the extended cut. However it is immensely satisfying and has three outstanding performances. Portman's career in my opinion has yet to produce a role so intriguing, Oldman comes across as chillingly both insane and rational, and Jean Reno plays his role spectacularly, capturing both the human and inhuman sides to the character. Although at times I needed to pause and digest it, it was undoubtedly a superb movie. Gritty and unafraid to make bold artistic choices.

title: Simply a masterpiece
content: I've watched this movie three times and the least I can say is that it is a masterpiece. Luc Besson perfectly managed to make us feel things through his movie. Natalie Portman is charming and her acting is great, as usual. Jean Reno succeeded at being at the same time a cold-hearted hit-man and an emotional sweetheart. Gary Oldman succeeded at being a villain. It is a smart action movie with a touch of love and comedy. A real thriller, leaving us speechless during all the movie, specially at the end. When the movie ended, I started asking myself questions about me and the world around me. Makes you think things all over again... and you just never get bored of this movie.

title: Admirable film.
content: Léon, to put it simply, is a masterpiece. One of the greatest early-modern films, no doubt about it. Natalie Portman at 12 is already excellent, and given a chance so few have: while there are many younger actors a mere handful can win these starring roles, and in serious films they're too young to see. Comparable to Kick-Ass, though this original suspense flies past the modern indie-wannabe in daylight. Nothing was stilted nor pushed too far and the story, yet unmentioned, is simply insightful. The only reason I give an 8, not 9 or even 10, is because 8 is my favourite number, and so only given to those which are worthy. The actors own their roles, and should play these characters more often. (This is) A favourite that will (unexpectedly?) last a long time.

title: Possibly the Best Action Film Ever Made
content: This movie is art in its purest state. It refuses to follow any boundaries of what should be done and what should not be done, what is acceptable and what is not acceptable. I have never seen a freer movie. It flies like a boundless bird above the mountains and hills and cities.The closest thing I can compare it to are those moments when the protagonist takes their love interest on a flight through the clouds. You the viewer are the love interest. The film is the dark and mysterious protagonist.But even looking past all that, and even looking past the mostly fantastic characters (Gary Oldman is hit-or-miss as the villain, but he does not ruin the film), this movie is fantastic because of its blend of art and action. Outside of MM: FR, I have never seen a movie that blends those two elements so gloriously. Under poor hands, art and action neuter each other. But under expert hands, they amplify each other and create something that will last, that deserves to last.I wish Besson would make another film this great, this beautiful.The first shot of the film is a pan shot over Central Park. Now, normally, this would be nothing more than a standard shot to show our setting, but they way they shoot it makes CP resemble a forbidden jungle or something of the sort, thus giving off the impression that this film will cover the dark and wild side of NYC. It is one of the best opening shots I've ever seen.Every time you think the story is going to zig, it zags. But nothing ever comes off as forced or contrived. In every good story, you are confident the creator knows what they're doing. I always got that feeling when I was watching this film. Combine that with the unconventionality I describes earlier and you have a truly beautiful piece of art.I'm willing to bet you'll feel uncomfortable at times when you're watching the film. This is not a bad thing. Art is not meant to keep you comfortable. It is meant to evoke and make you look at the world differently. There is nothing squicky enough to make any reasonable person turn off the film, but some of the interactions between the assassin and Natalie Portman can make some people shaky. Quickly: she grows to lust for him. He does not take advantage of that, but if you're turned off by such things, you're better off either not watching the film at all or watching the far inferior theatrical cut.This film is everything blockbusters want to be and everything they would never think of being. It is my favorite French film and one of my favorite foreign films. If you want a thoughtful and artistic yet adrenaline-pumping experience, go give it a watch.

title: 7.8/10 - Well-Directed, Full of Cartoonish Action and Fun Whimsicality
content: Luc Besson's 1994 film, Léon: The Professional, follows Léon, a deadly plant-loving, slow-thinking Italian hitman. This guy was just trying to go on with his steady life as a hitman when Mathilda, a 12-year-old girl whose family got murdered, forced his hand into letting her join him so she can take her revenge upon the cold-blooded killers of her little brother.A fair warning: a lot of people note that Mathilda and Léon's relationship glorifies p3d0philia, with which claim I tend to disagree.Luc Besson's original intentions were probably really problematic, considering the fact that Besson's partner at the time, Maïwenn, he met when she was 12 and he was 29, and he married after impregnating her at 16. She plays a side character in the movie's opening scene, and she sees Léon and Mathilda's relationship as something that's based on her and Besson's real-life marriage.I'd say that maybe because of the fact that Natalie Portman's parents were involved so much in the production, and maybe Luke Besson's fear of outright justifying grooming, the final product - the film itself - doesn't convey such messages. Problematic things happen but the film, in my eyes, mostly presents them in a negative light. That's it, you've been warned. Now, let's move on to talking about the film itself.This film is noticeably very well-directed, and it manages to be visually captivating without being too avant-garde for people to feel it's not accessible. The actions scenes are dynamic and fun (and quite creative), and there's not a single action scene that I haven't thoroughly enjoyed. There are some cartoonish qualities to the cinematography as well, and I think it's really cool. Adds to the general whimsicality that this film shows from time to time.Also, the score has no business going this hard. Éric Serra captures the suspense and aesthetic of the scenes he scores in a really accurate way, that totally enhances the scene. The music is also very well-produced and pleasant. If I'm talking about the music, might as well give a nod to the soundtrack. Bjork made me smile for like five whole minutes after the song ended. Love it.Léon is a really likeable character (Jean Reno delivers a great performance in my opinion), and I found myself quite invested in him. He's not complicated and layered or anything, he just works really well. Mathilda was quite annoying, to be honest, but obviously there is no film without Mathilda, and I also like a lot of the "cleaning" interactions between her and Léon. All the characters in the film are relatively simple but work well, built with enough thought, creativity and cool dynamics between them all to make this film a very enjoyable watch.Take the killers, for instance - each of them has his own thing, his standout personality that makes them feel more human. Props for that.I still wish that the film would've given me more reasons to like Mathilda, since the film definitely wants us to but I'm not really there. Hard for me to be totally invested in her as a main character, and that's definitely a flaw in the film in my eyes.So despite its problematic background, I think that Léon: The Professional is a good movie. It's funny, well-directed and full of iconic moments. The character dynamics are mostly fun and interesting, and even side characters feel like they have some personality. I think that this film would've benefited from making Mathilda a more likeable character, but still: it's a cartoonish, viby and quite badass film. Feeling a 7.8/10 on this one.
